learning context the way that you would learn about machine learning in a computer science class usually the goal
of using machine learning is to build an accurate model of your data so that perhaps you can make predictions on new
unseen data in the future all right super useful if you build that model it doesn't work very well often you're
going to change the algorithm and find a more suitable algorithm or you might change the features or you might say oh
I've got more data that I can you know collect and use a bigger data set that might often help as well but you you
don't want to mess around with the data too much because the data you talk about it as a ground truth right it embodies
some sort of truth about the world that you don't have access to other than through the data when people are
creating in interactions with machine learning a lot of these things change right people still might want to build a controller
that they would call accurate right there's for instance if I want to build a gaming controller that reacts to me
you know punching I wanted to always react a hundred percent of the time and not react otherwise but that accurate
controllers in the context of a larger goal which is I want to play a game that's fun that's accessible to people
that doesn't you know doesn't take practice to learn how to use or maybe I want to build an expressive musical
interface that gives me cool sounds that I can play onstage without looking stupid right there's all sorts of other
subjective complex goals here and sometimes changing the algorithm or
features are really good ideas but often changing the training data is the most effective and reasonable way to change
what the model is doing if it's not doing what you want so you saw that in the the camera example right when I
found a place where it made a mistake I was able to easily correct that by just giving it examples I'm like oh I
overlooked what it might you know what I should tell it to do when I'm standing here so I can fix that and we retrain
and we're good and so in HCI people people often talk about this as
human-in-the-loop approaches to machine learning or interactive machine learning machine learning researchers may mean
something slightly different when they talk about interactive machine learning and the reason that this makes sense
it's a complicated conversation but one of the reasons is that this data often
yeah there may be some kind of hidden truth in it that we can't articulate otherwise but it's the data is really
sort of user interface or communication channel between the person and the machine right it's my first training set
is my way of telling the computer what I want it to do and my subsequent training sets might be refinements of that those
instructions about what I want it to do and so this actually requires some
rethinking about what it is that we want the algorithm to do what makes a good algorithm and of course how we structure
the user interface right most other software environments especially software environments for
non-interactive not more conventional machine-learning don't make it this easy to mangle your training data because
that's a bad thing Weka Nader we you know I learned right away that that was gonna be super useful for people so we
need to have interfaces that allow the kinds of manipulations that make sense but this leads to some interesting
computational consequences in that you know people are gonna provide training data that is not iid right this is sort
of assumption that often we make for convenience and maybe even with good reason when we're talking about machine
learning theory but people turns out are often smarter than that and if we allow them to be smarter we take advantage of
the fact that they're smarter we can learn more efficiently so let's imagine we're building a musical instrument and
we're looking at maybe where my hand is in space and I want one sound to happen when my hand is in the purple and one
sound when my hand is in the orange if I were doing this in a more traditional machine learning context I might go out
and collect a bunch of data try to get the best data set possible and get a nice even sampling maybe from these two
regions and that would be a pretty good if small data set when people are using
Weka Nader's to build examples even when they don't know anything at all about machine learning often they'll start by
giving just a few examples maybe in the center of the purple in the center of the orange more or less and they're not
going to spend too much time worrying about it and then they'll build a model and see where that decision boundary is and if it's not exactly where they want
they're gonna add some corrective data so they may say well this is really purple and this is really orange and now
I'm gonna retrain and get my boundary keep testing keep doing that but here what I've done is I've learned
essentially the right decision boundary but I didn't have to provide all these other examples so it's kind of like the
same benefits that you would get from active learning but here instead of the algorithm saying hey please label these unlabeled data points it's the person
just doing what they naturally do and saying I'm gonna find where it makes a mistake and I'm just gonna give corrective examples there and of course
that only really works if you have an algorithm that's perfectly willing to trust that person and say yeah even if
you know even if that purple dot were way over there maybe I trust you and I'm gonna give you a super weird
decision boundary and do what we would normally call overfitting turns out if you try too hard not to over fit in many
of these interactive contexts people take that sort of personally and they say well the algorithms not listening to
me right I know what I'm doing and it's still not doing what I want Oh another
consequence of building the interface this way this was something that really I hadn't thought about it all until I
started working with people and observing how they were using the software is that people were using this
these changes to the training data not only to fine-tune the decision boundary and correct mistakes but actually to try
out different hypotheses about what they might build right so they might start out with an idea the way that I did with
the leap motion and say well what if what if I put this on here what if I put this on there and as soon as I have that
then I've got a prototype and I can play around with it and I can use my experimentation with that right away to
say well was that a good idea or not and if it was a good idea great maybe it was
a good idea but I found some other sound in there that I really liked and I could put that back in the data set or maybe I
didn't like it and so I can roll back and so on right so we can think about these changes to the data set as also
again people communicating hypotheses about something that might be fun or
likewise people exploring and saying hey I have an idea of the thing that might be cool is this learn about is this
gonna be learn about given the fact that I'm not willing to spend more than five minutes giving training examples right
and people often are involved in this negotiation with the algorithm to say well what's the most useful thing I can

all really valuable types of activities in any kind of design context right
